description:
This course will introduce students to key works of English literature written before 1660. It will explore the major literary genres of this period, as well as the social and cultural contexts in which they were produced. The course will examine how literature texts articulate changes in language and form, as well as in concepts of family, nation, and community during the medieval and early modern periods. 

See the English Department's website at www.english.upenn.edu for a description of the current offerings.
name: LITERATURE BEFORE 1660

values.comments:
This course will introduce students to key works of English literature written before 1660. It will explore the major literary genres of this period, as well as the social and cultural contexts in which they were produced. The course will examine how literature texts articulate changes in language and form, as well as in concepts of family, nation, and community during the medieval and early modern periods.

Students were moderately impressed with the quality of this course, with the main complaint being that the material studied was “boring, difficult, and fairly monotonous”. However, students appreciated the wealth of knowledge they received about medieval and renaissance literature. Therefore, they believed that the course was “an eminently suitable intro course in English.”

Professor Sanchez was well liked by her students and appreciated for the way she “did a good job communicating material that was not inherently interesting.” Although Professor Sanchez was able to effectively communicate the subject material to students, it was felt that the class could have benefited from “more class discussion rather than lecture.” Students also believed that the professor was very accessible and willing to discuss course content with students outside the classroom.

The course was deemed “extremely necessary for any English major” for the concepts learned were considered by students to give “a good foundation for other literature courses in the future”. To this regard, the course was not recommended for non-majors.
